questions.question_text_1: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 42,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk, what should be the maximum speed of disk in RPM so that the lens does not miss any data?
question_texts: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 42,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk, what should be the maximum speed of disk in RPM so that the lens does not miss any data?

options.option_text: Statements i and iii are correct
Statements ii and iv are correct
The tables are not at all related

questions.question_text_1: Read the statements given below carefully and select the correct option.  Statement 1:If an element having an ID and a class is styled externally using both its ID and the class, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest selector in order.  Statement 2: If an element that belongs to two different classes is styled externally using both the classes, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest class in order
question_texts: Read the statements given below carefully and select the correct option.  Statement 1:If an element having an ID and a class is styled externally using both its ID and the class, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest selector in order.  Statement 2: If an element that belongs to two different classes is styled externally using both the classes, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest class in order

options.option_text: Statement 1 is correct but statement 2 is incorrect
Statement 2 is correct but statement 1 is incorrect

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following graph that represents the variation in bandwidth of a network for an entire day (24 hours). Three users were connected to the network at three different times of the day. What is the total data consumed in GigaBytes by all the users in 24 hrs?

questions.question_text_1: You have a DRAM module with bus width of 64 bits, clock speed of 2 GHz, and operating in DDR (double-data-rate or two values per clock cycle) mode. What is the maximum bandwidth (in Giga-bytes per second) of data transfer achievable with this module?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** ### **1. Python & Flask** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Flask Routing & Views**: - Dynamic routes (``, ``). - Query parameters (`request.args`). - HTTP methods (`GET`, `POST`). - Error handling (`abort(404)`, `@app.errorhandler`). - **Jinja2 Templating**: - Template inheritance (`{% extends %}`, `{% block %}`). - Macros (`{% macro %}`). - Conditional rendering (`{% if %}`). - **Flask-SQLAlchemy**: - Model relationships (one-to-many, many-to-one). - Database sessions (`db.session.add`, `db.session.commit`). - Foreign keys (`db.ForeignKey`). - **Flask-RESTful**: - Request parsing (`reqparse.RequestParser`). - Resource-based routing (`api.add_resource`). - **Session Management**: - `flask.session` for user authentication. - `session.pop()` for logout. #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** ```python # Dynamic Route @app.route('/user/') def get_user(id): return f"User ID: {id}" # Query Parameters course = request.args.get('course') # Error Handling abort(404) # Returns 404 Not Found @app.errorhandler(404) def not_found(error): return "Page not found", 404 # Jinja2 Macro {% macro greet(name) %}

Hello, {{ name }}!

{% endmacro %} # SQLAlchemy Relationship (One-to-Many) class User(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) roles = db.relationship("Role", backref="user") class Role(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey("user.id")) ``` --- ### **2. HTML/CSS** #### **Key Concepts:** - **CSS Specificity**: - `!important` > Inline styles > IDs > Classes > Elements. - Later rules override earlier ones for the same specificity. - **Box Model**: - `display: block` vs. `inline` vs. `inline-block`. - `width`, `border`, `padding`, `margin`. - **Selectors**: - `.class`, `#id`, `element`. #### **Key Rules:** ```css /* Specificity Example */ #id { color: blue; } /* Higher specificity */ .class { color: red; } /* Lower specificity */ span { background: yellow; } /* Lowest specificity */ ``` --- ### **3. Testing (Pytest)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Test Selection**: - `-k` flag to filter tests by name. - `-m` flag to run tests with specific markers (`@pytest.mark.marker1`). - **Assertions**: - `assert func(x) == expected`. - **Fixtures**: - `@pytest.fixture` for reusable test data. - **Test Naming**: - Test functions must start with `test_` (e.g., `test_case1`). #### **Key Commands:** ```bash pytest test_file.py -k "Test_class" # Run tests with "Test_class" in name pytest test_file.py -m marker1 # Run tests marked with @pytest.mark.marker1 ``` --- ### **4. Networking & Hardware** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Bandwidth vs. Latency**: - **Bandwidth**: Data transfer rate (bits/second). - **Latency**: Time for data to travel (affected by distance and medium). - **DRAM Bandwidth**: - **Formula**: \[ \text{Bandwidth (GB/s)} = \frac{\text{Bus Width (bits)} \times \text{Clock Speed (Hz)} \times 2 \text{ (DDR)}}{8 \text{ (bits/byte)}} \] Example: 64-bit bus, 2 GHz clock, DDR → \( \frac{64 \times 2 \times 10^9 \times 2}{8} = 32 \text{ GB/s} \). - **IPv4 to Hexadecimal**: - Convert each octet to hex (e.g., `172.16.254.10` → `AC.10.FE.0A`). #### **Key Equations:** \[ \text{Latency (ms)} = \frac{\text{Distance (m)}}{\text{Speed of Light (m/s)}} \times 2 \text{ (round-trip)} \times 1000 \] Example: 9000 km cable (speed = \(1.5 \times 10^8\) m/s) + 9000 km air (speed = \(3 \times 10^8\) m/s): \[ \text{Total Latency} = \left( \frac{9 \times 10^6}{1.5 \times 10^8} + \frac{9 \times 10^6}{3 \times 10^8} \right) \times 2 \times 1000 = 180 \text{ ms} \] --- ### **5. Data Consumption Calculation** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Data Transfer**: - **Formula**: \[ \text{Data (GB)} = \frac{\text{Bandwidth (Mbps)} \times \text{Time (seconds)}}{8 \times 1024^2} \] - Example: 10 Mbps for 4 hours → \( \frac{10 \times 10^6 \times 4 \times 3600}{8 \times 1024^2} \approx 16.8 \text{ GB} \). --- ### **6. Software Testing Types** | **Type** | **Description** | |------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Regression Testing | Ensures new changes don’t break existing functionality. | | User Acceptance Testing| Validates software with end-users (e.g., beta testing). | | System Testing | Tests the complete system (hardware + software + environment). | | System Testing Automation | Automates system testing (e.g., Selenium for browser scripting). | --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **1. Flask & Web Development** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask] --> B[Routing] A --> C[Templating with Jinja2] A --> D[Request Handling] A --> E[Database with SQLAlchemy] A --> F[Error Handling] B --> B1[Dynamic Routes: /user/] B --> B2[Query Parameters: request.args] C --> C1[Macros] C --> C2[Template Inheritance] D --> D1[GET/POST Methods] D --> D2[request.form vs request.args] E --> E1[Model Relationships] E --> E2[db.session] F --> F1[abort(404)] F --> F2[@app.errorhandler] ``` ### **2. CSS Specificity & HTML Rendering** ```mermaid graph TD A[CSS] --> B[Specificity Rules] A --> C[Box Model] B --> B1[!important] B --> B2[Inline Styles] B --> B3[IDs] B --> B4[Classes] B --> B5[Elements] C --> C1[display: block/inline] C --> C2[width/margin/padding] ``` ### **3. Testing with Pytest** ```mermaid graph TD A[Pytest] --> B[Test Selection] A --> C[Fixtures] A --> D[Markers] B --> B1[-k flag: Keyword filtering] B --> B2[-m flag: Marker filtering] C --> C1[@pytest.fixture] D --> D1[@pytest.mark.marker1] ``` ### **4. Networking & Hardware** ```mermaid graph TD A[Networking] --> B[Bandwidth] A --> C[Latency] A --> D[IP Addressing] B --> B1[DRAM Bandwidth Calculation] C --> C1[Speed of Light in Cable/Air] C --> C2[Round-Trip Time] D --> D1[IPv4 to Hexadecimal] ``` ### **5. Database Relationships (SQLAlchemy)** ```mermaid graph TD A[SQLAlchemy] --> B[One-to-Many] A --> C[Many-to-One] A --> D[Many-to-Many] B --> B1[User --> Roles] C --> C1[Role --> User] D --> D1[Association Tables] ``` ### **6. Software Testing Types** ```mermaid graph TD A[Testing] --> B[Regression Testing] A --> C[User Acceptance Testing] A --> D[System Testing] A --> E[Automation Testing] B --> B1[Ensures no breaks after changes] C --> C1[Beta Testing] D --> D1[Full system validation] E --> E1[Selenium/Pytest] ```
